Award.AwardTitle: Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Atlanta Lecture Series in Graph Theory and Combinatorics, which will be held November 11-12, 2017 and April 21-22, 2018 at Georgia Institute of Technology and Emory University, respectively. Combinatorics and graph theory have undergone dramatic development in the past few decades. These two conferences will feature the latest research developments and themes in the areas of structural graph theory, extremal graph theory, and probabilistic combinatorics. The series has become a major event for the combinatorics community, providing opportunities to strengthen collaborations among researchers and institutions within the southeast region of the United States.

Each conference features two one-hour lectures by a distinguished researcher, four one-hour lectures by established researchers mainly from the southeast region, and four 30-minute talks by early-career researchers and graduate students. The meetings provide opportunities for interaction among established researchers and rising stars; this award supports the attendance of graduate students, early-career researchers, and invited speakers. Additional information concerning financial support and the conference schedule is maintained at the lecture series website: http://www.als.math.gatech.edu/

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the academic year 2017-2018, we proposed to organize two mini-conferences for Atlanta Lecture Series (ALS) in Combinatorics and Graph Theory. The rst mini-conference (ALS20) was successfully held at Georgia Institute of Technology on the weekend of Sep 30-Oct 1, 2017 and the second one (ALS21) was held at Emory University on the weekend of April 21-22, 2018.

ALS19: Organizer Xingxing Yu, Georgia Institute of Technology

The Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory XX was held at Georgia Institute of Technology on Sep 30 to Oct 1, 2017. The conference featured two 1-hour talks by Paul Seymour, from Princeton University. Also featured were 1 hour talks by Patrick Bennett, Western Michigan University; Guoli Ding, Louisiana State University; Jie Ma, University of Science and Technology of China; Matas Sileikis, Charles University; and Richard Wilson, California Institute of Technology. These talks were supplemented by one 25 minute talks by junior faculty and graduate students: Chi Ho Yuen, Georgia Institute of Technology.

The conference web page can be found at:
http://als.math.gatech.edu/schedule/


ALS21: Organizer Hao Huang, Emory University

The Atlanta Lecture Series (ALS) in Combinatorics and Graph Theory XXI (ALS21) was held at Emory University on April 21-22, 2018. The conference featured two 1-hour talks by Jacques Verstraete, from University of California San Diego. Also featured were four 1 hour talks by Theo Molla, University of South Florida; Bhargav Narayanan, Rutgers Unviersity; Hoi H. Nyugen, Ohio State University; and Xavier Perez Gimenez, University of Nebraska-Lincoln. These talks were supplemented by 25 minute talks by junior faculty and graduate students: Andrii Arman, University of Manitoba; Anton Bernshteyn, University of Illinis Urbana-Champaign; Laura Eslava, Georgia Tech; and Lisa Sauermann, Stanford University.

The conference web page can be found at:
http://www.mathcs.emory.edu/~hhuan30/ALS/ALS21/index.html

Thus, as proposed, the mini-conferences featured some of the top combinatorists in the country, as well as provided an opportunity for some younger faculty and graduate students to present their work. As such, we met all our goals stated in the proposal. These 16 researchers, received travel and local expense support to speak at the conference. This award also supported a number of junior researcherrs and student participants to travel from nearby cities.

Both mini-conferences were very well attended. The mini-conference schedule and an abstract for each talk is included in this report.
